Climate Change and Carbon Cycling

Our aim is to understand the chemical transformations of plant-derived organic compounds in soil and the impact of soil and crop management practices on the global environment providing tools for investigation of strategies to minimise adverse effects. Some of our studies utilise models and long-term experiments to elucidate the impacts of cropping systems on soil organic matter and impacts of global environmental change on soils and agricultural systems. Particular emphasis is on the storage of carbon in soil organic matter and scaling issues.
Measuring and modelling soil carbon dynamics
Long term soil C changes and SOMNET

Soil organic matter changes slowly in temperate regions, following changes in land use and management, and it often takes over 20 years to observe a significant change in soil C content. At Rothamsted, we have a unique resource for studying long-term soil C dynamics: the Long-Term and Classical experimental plots. (... more).
The broadbalk continuous winter wheat experiment, started in 1843.

Soils play an important role in global climate and as shown by our preliminary work with SOMNET data, there is considerable potential to manipulate soils to offset climate change. Signatory states to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change must provide detailed national emissions inventories that fully report all anthropogenic sources of greenhouse gases. The Kyoto Protocol also allows carbon credits (CO2 removed from the atmosphere) to be offset against CO2 emissions, including agricultural soils. (... more).
Figure from Falloon et al, 2002, Soil Use and Management, 18, 164-174.

The soil micro-organisms (e.g. fungi, yeasts, protozoans, algae, bacteria etc.) have been described as 'the eye of the needle' through which all organic matter must pass as it is mineralized to its basic inorganic components (e.g. C, N, P and S).  In the Soil Biomass Group we are mainly studying the microorganisms as a 'black box' or single undifferentiated pool of soil organic matter.  To do this we have developed a number of methods to measure the biomass, which are now used worldwide.  This approach enables us to study, for example, transformations and cycling of the major nutrients in ways which would be impossible if we studied the soil micro-organisms individually.  This approach has also shed light on the survival strategies of this vital soil component, without which all life on earth would soon become extinct.
